item.description:
In Kosminen kierros ("Cosmic Tour"), the players are astronauts flying in a spaceship circumnavigating and exploring the solar system. Each player shares responsibility for ensuring that the ship makes it safely back to Earth, but at the same time should try to collect as much information about the solar system to win the game when the ship makes it back to Earth.
The game has two separate game boards. The first board represents the solar system, on which the players' spaceship pawn is moved. If the ship flies off the grid, hits a planet or the sun, the ship is destroyed and all players lose the game. The board also includes Event-markers, which are turned over when the ship flies on them, and have a surprising impact on game play.
The other board represents the inside of the spaceship, where players move their astronaut pawns. Each turn, a player must move from one module of the spaceship to another and carry out an action. The actions that can be carried out in the different modules are:
-Bridge: turn the ship's inclination (to determine which direction the ship moves in)
-Observatory: draw two Data cards (giving points at the end of the game)
-Storage: draw two Equipment cards (useful items to be used during the game to save the ship from destruction or help the player's own game
-Engine room: move the ship pawn forward one step.

The game has three levels of game play with increasing complexity. On level two, Captain's Orders cards are added to the game, which are played whenever a player moves to the Bridge, giving that player an additional action. Also, the scoring system for Data cards becomes based on set collection. On level three, Escape pods are included, which allow a player to win the game even if the ship is destroyed.

This game was custom designed to order, and is intended mainly for a specific target market, i.e. children aged 8-14. It is an educational game at heart, in which the players learn about the solar system, and the importance of working together for a common goal, while having lots of fun. But naturally anybody can play it, and it works specially well as a game that the whole family can enjoy together

item.description:
MathAnimals is an exciting new game that teaches and reinforces addition, subtraction or multiplication skills for children for all ages. With the roll of a die, players race around the colorful game board trying to land their playing piece on the animal that represents the highest number. Then they either add, subtract or multiply the number on the die to the number they have landed on. The winner is the first to have their grand
total reach the goal, a number that is set at the beginning of each new game.

Kids hop animal-shaped playing pieces around a colorful playing path, passing through eight different animal habitats, "Critter City," "Polar Snowland," "Big Sky Prairie," "Endless Desert," "Wild Wild Woods," "Dripping Wetlands," "Yak Yak Mountain," and "Teeming Rainforest." At each habitat, they attempt to win Animal Medallions by answering "Who's At Home?" questions. Examples: "What animal is the largest hunter on the African savanna?" "Why won't a polar bear ever meet, greet, or eat a penguin in the wild?" "What are earths, setts, and warrens?" Answers, with a line or two of explanation, are listed after each question.

Winner is the first to collect all eight Animal Medallions and answer one final question from the "Who's At Home?" square in the center of the board.

A British geography board game, in which globe-trotting kids move their playing pieces across a map of the world, attempting to send postcards home from six different cities: Cape Town, London, New York, Rio de Janeiro, Sydney, and Tokyo. As they move from place to place, they must answer general-knowledge "Journey Questions" or geography-related "Postbox Questions." (Example: "What is the name of the longest river in the world?") Once players have reached a target city and correctly answered a Postbox Question, they get to mail a postcard home. The postcards are real cards: kids address them, write or draw a message, stamp the cards with a cancellation rubber stamp, and drop them into a bright-red British-style postbox, assembled from folded cardboard.

A game for 2-6 players. Each player moves an ambulance from the rescue station, following the grey streets around town and back to goal at the rescue station. First ambulance back wins the game.
While driving through town the players might land on a red square and draw a card. This will either be an easy rescue-themed question or an in-game effect (extra roll or wait a turn). 
Or they might land on yellow squares, giving them and their ambulance an assignment (detour) around the city.

There is a mild educational theme to this game. You will have to follow traffical rules and there are 9 different questions about rescue situations.

item.description:
Behind The Glass is a card game where players manage their own TV Channels and try to earn the most viewers from 4 different target groups by designing the most efficient schedule each day. Their aim in the short-run is to fulfill advertising contracts to get money and in the long-run to gain viewers from those groups which eventually will give them victory.

The action phase is played by using employees cards in order to perform common or special (more efficient) actions. Each employee card represents either a unique special action or a boost of a common action. Each employee, after he/she has been played is discarded. So players must constantly plan their hand keeping in mind the hand limit and the emploeyees available in market.

Players must manage their daily schedule by purchasing Films and placing them face down next to current day's viewers. Each film has a quality and a duration which constraints the available slots (for example, movies take 3 zones, so a player cannot place a movie in zone 1 and then place another film in zone 2). Also, some employees can boost this quality during the broadcasting phase, producing unexpected results! Films can also be used as advertisments of the channel. They can be discarded in order to grant 1 quality in a matching viewer of the next day's program. Finally, films, according to their type, may give players important end game bonuses (for example, fulfilling an action series 3 times, thus completing a season, will grant 10 working class viewers at the end of the game).

At the beginning players do not have any money. They will go in red as they will buy films and workers but soon they will need to fulfill advertising contracts in order to get money (or play some shows) and become profitable. At the end money will be added (or subtracted) to the final score. Advertising contracts can give a lot of money if they are fulfilled before expiration (some employees can extend those contracts).

Finally, players have the ability to create their own custom films and then use them for their program or sell them for good money. Also, designing internal productions is the only way to get Managers who give strong and long-term abilities.

Are you ready to manage a TV Channel efficiently? Getting most viewers is a must but at the same time you have to do it in the most profitable way!

The Wizard of the Tribe has died. As it has been recorded by our ancestors, for thousands of years wizard-wannabes made their predictions for the ostrich race in the Holy Cave, the one making the more accurate predictions becoming the new Wizard. Which ostrich will win the race? Who will become the new Wizard? The answers are not easy since it is an open secret that candidates are not limited just to making predictions...

In Banjooli Xeet players become Wizards who must predict the order of arrival of racing ostriches in order to gain points, while dodging obstacles, collecting berries, avoiding the dreaded Lion, and not waking the sleeping crocodiles. Banjooli Xeet is a fast-paced race game for 2 to 5 players with a lot of bluffing, crazy predictions and hilarious fun.



El Brujo de la Tribu ha muerto. Tal como dejaron escrito nuestros antepasados, miles de años atrás, los aspirantes realizarán sus predicciones para la carrera de avestruces en la gruta sagrada y el que realice la más exacta será el nuevo Brujo de la Tribu. ¿Qué avestruz ganará la carrera? ¿Quién se convertirá en nuevo brujo? Son respuestas difíciles, ya que es un secreto a voces que los aspirantes no se limitan simplemente a hacer predicciones…En Banjooli Xeet los jugadores son Brujos y deben predecir el orden de llegada de los avestruces para ganar puntos, sortear obstáculos, recoger bayas, evitar al temido León, no despertar a los dormidos cocodrilos. Banjooli Xeet es un juego rápido de 2 a 5 jugadores con mucho faroleo, locas predicciones y diversión hilarante.

item.description:
"Bridge comes easy with the partner racks. Two can play. The help you need to take yourself up to competition standard." (From box)

Beginners to Winners Bridge begins with modified rules to teach the concepts of Bridge, but also includes rules for Contract Bridge with four players.

With the included two-player rules, all 52 cards are dealt out. While both sets of partner cards are face down, both players make their first bid. Once this has been done, each player will set up his partner cards in his partner rack, according to suit. The card racks hold the cards at 45-degree angles, allowing a person to see the cards opposite them, but not their opponent's cards. Each player will play the cards in their partner rack as well as his own cards. The bidding continues as each player studies their partner hand as well as their own. Players can raise the bid until 7 NT is bid or until one player passes.

There is a simplified scoring system for the beginners' game. One point is given for each trick won. Both the Declarer and the Defender can win these points. If the Declarer wins at least the number of tricks called for, they win a bonus of 10 points. If he doesn't, the Defender wins a bonus of 5 points and the Declarer deducts 1 point for each Undertrick. The first player to score 30 points wins the game.

Crown Duels is a 2-player card game that uses a standard deck of playing cards and an optional, self-printable playing mat.

The aim of the game is to destroy your opponent’s Nobility (picture cards) before they destroy yours.

Play requires hand management and a variety of simple rock, paper, scissors type comparisons using suits that play-out as a series of skirmishes between foot soldiers, trying to defend their Nobility from attack.

44 cards, all showing characters at the fox-hunt; Hounds, Lady Riders, Huntsmen, the Fox and the Whip.
All the cards are dealt to each player. After dealing one card to each player, the dealer must add one to the pool as well so that the game starts with a number of cards in the pool. Each player is given 24 counters. The person holding the Whip card cries "Tally Ho!" and asks the player of his choice if he has the Fox card. Various penalties occur if he is right or wrong. Then the Whip is placed into the pool cards, which are now shuffled.
Now each player asks a player for a card, and if he makes a trick, he can claim it in front of him. Then he takes a number of counters from the pool and adds them to his other counters. If a pair of Hounds is played, he collects 3 counters, a pair of Lady Riders, 6 counters; a pair of huntsmen, 9 counters; a special pair of the Whip and the Fox, 12 counters and that trick counts as two tricks at the end of the game. All cards in the pair must match numbers as well as images.
When all the cards are collected as pairs, the player with the most tricks takes the remaining counters in the pool, and the one with the most counters, wins.

One of a range of cheaper games in the early 20th century. I have no rules but it looks like a simple roll-and-move game, but the publisher has tied it to an oriental theme, for no reason than the Orient was a popular subject at the time.

This is a free analog of General Wellesley (later Wellington) and Scindia in India "King"in the great battle, the battle for the decisive battle of the war, later recalled this Wellington His campaign is a campaign to fight the best.
The game includes a map, the operator 9 * 6 plates and a help card, these parts include only the print is free of charge can be used directly.
Fighting is the result obtained by direct roll, no CRT, but not so simple. Including the impact and fire fighting methods, different branches of the military way of fighting have some differences. There are 5 scenario, the victory conditions vary.

In Mare Balticum each player takes the role of a captain of a fleet of fishing boats. Your task is to catch fish in the choppy waters of the Baltic Sea. Which fish should you try for? The noble salmon, delicious cod, schools of herring, or perhaps the flounders deep in the mud? Or maybe forget about the stinking fish business and focus on collecting beautiful Baltic amber from the water?

Whatever decision is taken, captains must also deliver goods to appropriate ports and sell them. Whoever most effectively handles the task and makes a fortune before winter comes and freezes the Baltic waters will be the winner!

item.description:
From the Manufacturer:
Object of the game is to be the first player to flip their 4 tokens from "Stressed to Blessed", "Tired to Inspired", "Frazzled to Dazzled", and "Mad to Glad" simply by looking on the positive side of life! Spin the spinner, find the silver lining, and collect cards to come out a winner. Count Your Blessings is all about finding the "bright side" to each scenario on the cards, no matter how big the challenge, and seeing that every situation in life is full of "blessings-in-disguise". The Youngest player goes first by spinning the spinner. The corresponding card is read, a silver lining response is given, and in some cases, voted on. See specific card instructions below. Play continues in a clockwise direction until one player wins the game by turning all 4 tokens over to the sunny yellow side!

Contents:

 1 sun spinner board, 
 215 game cards, 
 24 tokens, 
 6 heads or tails coins, 
 1 pair Look on the Brightside glasses

name.value: Chicken Soup for the Preteen Soul

item.description:
Another game from the Chicken Soup series.
Player answer questions about things that are important to preteens in order to collect six "Life's Ingredients" cards (happiness, love, hope, joy, faith, and peace).

CRY H.A.V.I.C. (Heavy Assault Vessel Infantry Carrier) is a table-top futuristic SF 25 mm miniature game for two or more players. The game requires miniature figures to represent troops on the battlefield. Talon Games produced a line of CRY H.A.V.I.C. miniatures.

Set in the 26th century, mighty empires clash for valuable worlds and the resources and power they provide. Power armor soldiers and intelligent M.A.R.S. (Mobile Assault Robotic Soldiers) units make up the bulk of fighting forces with the H.A.V.I.C. carrying them through space from one battlefield to another. More than merely armored transports, H.A.V.I.C.s serve a base of operations for its troops. (From back cover)

The rulebook has been designed to teach the gamer how to play in and to better understand the universe of Cry H.A.V.I.C. Each area of the rulebook falls under one of four headings.

The Introduction: This section describes the background of the game's universe and provides details on some of the major events that helped to shape the galaxy as it is in the year 2572.

The Rules: The rules section explains the concepts, techniques and philosophy of the game. The rule book says that it can accommodate a wide number of units per side but recommends that starting players begins with 5-7 units per side and then add additional troops.

Equipment and Design: This section describes some of the equipment that could be found on the modern battlefield as well as the basic military formations and setup of the two major powers in the game system: The Terran Confederation and The Ryuuza Imperium.

The Universe: This part details some of the many personalities that are found in the Cry H.A.V.I.C. gaming universe. A short story is also included here. (From rule book)

It is a 25 mm miniature game which uses d10 for all rolls. Distances in the game are measured in inches. Each square inch of the gaming table represents an area 5 feet across. The turn is 30 seconds long and is broken up into two rounds of 15 seconds. Each round is made up of four action phases which are used to organize the actions of every unit.

"A game which uses ordinary playing cards in a new and fascinating way" Box blurb 
Cards are played 1 at a time to activate pieces on the board. Pieces are moved to scoring positions and do battle with opposing pieces by stacking up in a line "battery" and overpowering the opposition.

This is a set of rules to play a WWII game with 1:144 miniatures. It doesn't use a lot of look up tables, and is easy to learn. That's why I call it "Quick War". This set of rules uses no game board, instead units are moved by measurements in inches, and rulers are used also for firing weapons. I use different colors of felt to denote hills, forest, water, and roads. Units may be hidden and put on opportunity fire, or be activated to move and fire. There are rules for artillery and infantry as well. Infantry may be used as artillery spotters, or to attack other infantry or armor. There is also Infantry support which includes heavier weapons such as bazookas.

This is a game about a fishing competition. Players toss a die to move around the board as they attempt to land on the best fishing holes. Randomly drawn fish cards indicate the weight of the trophy fish. Cards are kept secret from the other players during the competition. Players must also head for the bait shop in order to keep fishing. The game ends after a player reaches the dock... points are scored for the weight of each trophy fish and the player with the most points is declared the winner.

Includes the board, six tokens, fish cards, bait markers, a die, and the rules.
72 Cards. Each one summarises an event in the life of a French King. Players must fill in the blanks. Answers supplied in an accompanying booklet.

Players take turns rolling the die, and stacking either towers of fruit (game 1) or just the fruit itself (game 2.)

Dexterity game similar to Jenga and Bandu with very nice wood pieces shaped like fruit.

Pieces are selected according to the result of the die roll.

Numa is an abstract strategy game in which players use simultaneous movement to try to get pieces adjacent to each other on an 8x8 board. The pieces are in four shapes (triangle, square, circle, and pentagon) and have an Arabic number on one side and a Roman numeral on the other. Movement is done by revealing a colored stone that indicates the direction that the chosen piece will move in. If the adjacent pieces are showing the same number style on their face-up side, they score the total value of the showing numbers. One player scores points for Arabic number matches and the other for the Roman Numeral matches. The first player to 30 points is the winner.

Missile Match is an abstract strategy game in which players use simultaneous movement to try to get four pieces adjacent to each other (orthogonally or diagonally) on a 4x8 board. Players randomly draw four dominoes and place them face down along the edge of the game board to "launch" missiles onto the playing field. The dominoes are revealed simultaneously. The number on the far side of the domino is the power of the missile and the number on the near side of the domino (closest to the player) is the distance the missile fires. If two missiles land on the same space, the one with the higher power wins and knocks the other one of the board. Blank spaces on dominoes allow for players to remove an opponents piece. The first person to get four missiles in a row in the playing area is the winner.

Nelaxtam is an abstract strategy game in which players are trying to land troops on an island, represented by a 12x12 board. Each space on the board is marked with a white or black marker and the goal is to destroy your opponents territory and remove those markers from the board. Troop movement and action is revealed simultaneously by both players. Troops can either move or destroy an adjacent enemy territory. The game is over once one player cannot position any of his five troops in a position to destroy further enemy territory. The player who has removed the most enemy territory is the winner.

The winter ice will soon be swept out of the Noort River, and the new trading season for furs will will begin. All winter, Indians have been trapping beaver and other fir-bearing animals. They are now on their way to Dutch Fort Orange, 150 miles north of New Amsterdam, with bundles of pelts for sale. You have stocked your sturdy ship with a selection of desirable trade goods, welcome to both settlers and Indians alike. Your task is to sail to Fort Orange, selling your trade goods at a profit along the way, arriving at Fort Orange ready to buy furs. Time is precious as you look for the best price to buy, then sailing back to New Amsterdam (or New England) to sell your cargo of furs at a profit.

Color Quest is a "magical strategy game for 2-3 players. Players travel the board using color, acquiring gold, gems and magical abilities." This is "a computer-assisted board game, where room contents are preselected by computer, and hints progressively revealed to players... Once a player has 25,000 gold pieces, and at least 1 Power Square, they may attempt to win." Other players may attempt to thwart the victory attempt and win themselves.

All quotes are taken from the designer's website.

Fantasy Franchise is "a real estate game where players purchase franchises, lease space in central Florida malls, and eventually purchase the malls themselves!" The malls feature "everything from movie theatres to Mall Security. Nearly all the names are tongue in cheek." The names of the stores and movie posters feature puns and parodies of popular brands such as "Taxi Driver II: My Fare, Lady!" and "While You Were Sleeping... the Movie Ended"

All quotes are taken from the designer's website.

Castles & Caverns is a fantasy game in which players try to "build the most beautiful castle", but are faced with numerous challenges. The game features "magic and swordplay combined with bidding and strategy, and of course, lots of treasure!" The game board is marked with four cavern areas, "Spire Falls", "Gold Ridge", "Ice Flow", and "Enchanted."

All quotes are taken from the designer's website.

Alchemy is an "exploration and resource management game for 2-3 players." Players use alchemy ..... Combine different color powders to gain special abilities, or find the best trading routes to maximize your profit. Players score victory points on gold, unused workers, and magic spells (the amount of victory points is somewhat variable since alchemy can be applied to the items to adjust the point values).

All quotes are taken from the designer's website.

Heroes of the Solar System is "an educational science game for 2-4 players who provide supplies to mankind's colonies throughout the solar system. The colonists on each planet need different things to survive, and award "Rescue Points" to the player who offers them the most of what they need." The game is designed for team play.

All quotes are taken from the designer's website.

Clockworks is a betting game based on Poker. There is a card dealt into the middle of the table which is shared among all players' hands. When a player is dealt a card of the same suit it dealt, he or she can pay to replace the card in the center of the table. Subsequent players can buy the replaced card for their own hand in lieu of being dealt a card. The common card that will actually be used for all hands isn't actually known until the end of the hand. The winner is determined using the regular rules of poker.

Revolver is a betting game based on Poker. Players are each dealt two face down cards and then select face up cards from two rows in the table to build their hands. Players bet and then following this, another two rows are dealt which players select cards from. Players bet and the receive one more card dealt face down. The winner is determined using the regular rules of poker.

Auction Poker is a card game based loosely on Poker. Eight cards are dealt face up and players use special bidding cards (1-5 per player) to win the cards to build their hands. Directional cards (1-3, "across" and "down") indicate the position of the cards being bid on that round. Players reveal their bids and the lowest bidder gets first selection of three identified cards or one face down card from the deck. After all players have built their hands, the winner is determined using the regular rules of poker.

Louis XVI is a tafl style game in which players must try to help King Louis XVI escape from an angry mob. The king player receives one king piece and an army of 18. The mob player gets 26 pieces. Play is set on a star shape board. Captures are done by jumping adjacent enemy pieces and are compulsory. The mob wins if the king is captured and the king player wins by getting the king piece to any of the points of the star.

Party Gras, billed as "Bourbon Street in a box", is a game of drinking, groping and flashing. Players are given strings of beads, which they can lose to, or acquire from, other players by way of instructions on the spinner or spaces on the board.

In true Mardi Gras fashion, bead exchanges are most often accomplished by flashing other players, or having other players flash you. The rules state that this involves baring one's chest, but also suggest that guys may be "a bit more creative".

The base mechanic is "spin and move" as the player's pieces (shot glasses) move along a winding track. Players must follow the directions on the spinner and board. The person holding the most strings of beads when any player crosses the finish line is the official winner.

According to the box, this game was designed to help players become safer drivers.

Players start with $3,260 and make a $250 down payment on their "Klunka" (car) to start the game. On each turn, the player rolls the dice to travel along the highway and draws a card, following its instructions. Cards may instruct the player to go to various points on the board, recite a tongue twister, pay a fine, go to jail, earn money or answer a driver test question.

First player to get 10 points on driver test questions, make four payments on their Klunka, and have $5,000 wins the game.

The Shade of Zombie is a merger between game of strategy and game of letters where the player must manage eliminate the Zombies against which he is to be able to count. A slightly conventional mechanics drags the player to a combat against enormous hordes Zombies.

The game this one thought to receive added since they can be new cards with new values and attributes beside introducing concrete areas of game since it can be boards and scenery.

It uses several systems of game of exclusive creation since it is CdB's Runic System and the System sequence to establish dynamic not cyclical shifts.

The aim of the players is to eliminate Zombies, nevertheless the game this one very modified since all the systems for which it operates have been designed separately, we will see that systems have used and his application in game.

The system of shifts "System Sequence" is a system of shifts for level of priority, this is established by the value of the Zombies against which we fight.

Initially of the game every player receives 2 Zombies's cards establishing by means of the sum of his values a total quantity that will be his priority of game.

Procedure: maximum of 3 Zombies for player, increase of priority for the not irresolute Zombies and decrease for the irresolute Zombies.

This gives like proved a different value between players and the order of the shifts decides, the system repeats itself during the whole item and this gives like proved a different order from shifts constant.

The player once in his shift must resort to eliminating Zombies, for this it was using a special system of so called combat " SEDD Runic " formed by 3 cards that give like proved combinations two-color on having placed in pyramidal formation.

Every Zombie that the player possesses in front of, includes 4 cards that in his set they form combinations Two-color, similar to the combinations obtained for BE Runic, using BE and in similarity of combinations the player ire withdrawing segments of the Zombies up to managing to eliminate them.

There are 3 types of Zombies, the positives " increase priority " negatives " diminish priority " and puntuables " they allow on having played to count for the final inventory ".

Once it is achieved to count, the player must study where to count since we speak about the system Faction.

The system Faction is a system of punctuations for faction, this one based on a board divided by 2 different decrees, the first board that is completed is used for the final inventory. Every section can include a maximum of 10 points, nevertheless the players only possess a maximum of 6 cards to include in the board, thus the system of punctuation is established like strategically.

The system of shifts, the system of combat and the system of punctuation are 3 bases on which Zombie operates on The Shade of, his architecture has as aim be strategic for the player since on having established a correct strategy, the shifts can be extended, we can create alliances between players and can create a sequential strategy of shifts that give us mas opportunities against another player for the simple fact of creating an order of shifts based on the basic calculation of increase and level decrease of priority.

All that achieves by means of 25 cards that there includes the game that they are the technical base of all his development, whereas the rest of components alone are cards to mark condition and others both with the player and with the Zombies.

It paginates of exhibition: http://cdb.creatuforo.com/the-shade-of-zombies-tema68.html

J: The Misere Connection Game is in the family of connection games that include Hex and Gonnect. It is unique in that players can win if they force their opponent to form a connection between two areas on the board, and takes place on an 8x4 board.

The origins of this game date back to a failed attempt to come up with a connection game for Stonehenge, which had an outer track that is very long but very tight. The shift to a set 8x4 board caused the game to be viewed differently than on the circular board of Stonehenge.

Another unique aspect to J is that players can LOSE the game if they form a certain type of connection, which would be a misere condition in a connection game. This is also a a unique feature. I had been pondering how to do one and J provides the opportunity to do this.

The game also features several other uncommon features, besides the small board and misere game ending condition, like piece recycling, and also entire lines of pieces being pushed.

¡Combate en una épica batalla espacial!
Las cinco razas más poderosas de la galaxia se enfrentan en un estratégico combate por el control de la galaxia Zyrcan... ¿serás lo suficientemente hábil con tus naves?

Contenido del juego:
-1 Tablero
- 60 fichas de nave (12 por jugador)

Objetivo:
Los jugadores ponen todas sus naves en la galaxia Zyrcan y luego entablan una encarnizada batalla por su control. El jugador que más naves consiga tener al final de la batalla será el ganador.


Fight in an epic space battle!
The five most powerful races in the galaxy face off in a strategic battle for control of the galaxy Zyrcan ... Will you be skillful enough with your ships?

Game content:
- 1 Boardgame
- 60 ship Tokens (12 each player)

Goal:
The players put all their ships in the Zyrcan galaxy and then engage in a fierce battle for control. The player gets to have more ships at the end of the battle will be the winner.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Go on a cross-town scavenger hunt to practice geometry and graphing! Coordinate cards direct players to move to different community places. Flip cards over to see if you moved correctly. Game board features positive coordinates on one side, and both positive and negative coordinates on the reverse for more advanced play.
 Add the fun of a scavenger hunt to geometry lessons! Teaches the Cartesian plane in a real-world context. Board features positive coordinates on one side, and both positive and negative coordinates on the reverse for more advanced play.
 - Draw an x-y coordinate card
- Use the game board coordinates to move your pawn to the location on your card
- Look at the community building picture on the back of your card to see if you moved correctly; if so, mark the location off your checklist
- Finish your checklist first to win!
-Positive and Negative Cartesian Coordinates

Contents:

 150 Coordinate Cards
 4 Game Pawns
 Scavenger-hunt Checklist
 Double-sided Game Board

The goal is to name countries and capitals that start with the letters on the five Letter Dice, and that are within the continents on the two Continent Dice. With colorful dice and a two-sided Game Board that doubles as a world map, GeoDice is a beguiling introduction to world geography! A fun way to learn geography! Roll into world knowledge with GeoDice, a game that makes geography fun!

Contents:

 Game Board world Map, 
 5 Letter Dice, 
 2 Continent Dice, 
 Dice Shaker, 
 Sand Timer, 
 Scorecard, 
 Rules
 Country/Capital List

Need a Vacation? Snapshots Across America, The Vacation Fantasy Game you can play at home. Travel across a game board map of the U.S.A. by car, train, boat or plane to see top tourist attractions from all 50 states. But watch out for bad weather! A hurricane, blizzard, tornado or other bad weather could spoil your vacation. Win by being the first to visit 7 different tourist attractions that are pictured on the cards. A fun way to learn U.S. Geography and discover great vacation destinations. Average game plays 15-20 minutes. Ages: 8 and Up, 2-6 Players

A dexterity / party game, in which player compete to form shapes with Lego bricks, based on the non-verbal information of the other players in their teams. Contains different cards with shapes worth a variable amount of points.

In Was klotzt du?, the players try to explain a concept using a set of wooden blocks.

The game is played in timed rounds. In each round, one player is the explainer, while the other players try to guess the concept. The explainer receives a set of 24 blocks (consisting of 11 brown blocks and 13 blocks of other colours). He is also given a card which tells him the concept that he has to explain using the blocks. He may not talk or make sounds, though he may move the blocks. He can also give a hint by placing one of his non-brown blocks in one of the circles on the board that show different categories.

If one of the other players successfully guesses the concept, he gets the card and the block used to give a hint (if any). Then, all non-brown blocks are placed aside, and the explainer receives a new card, and continues to explain the new concept with the remaining blocks. This continues until the time runs out, after which the results are scored. The explainer receives points for each concept he has explained, and each other player receives points for each concept he has guessed. Each concept is worth 1 to 4 points, depending on the amount of non-brown blocks that have been set aside. The more blocks that have been used during the round, the higher the value of the concepts.

Now, a new round begins, and the next player becomes the explainer. The game ends after each player has been the explainer thrice; the player who has gathered the most points wins.

Hit the ice with 2-3-4 Play Air Hockey! This multi-player arcade
style game captures all the action of real air hockey - right on your tabletop! Listen as real air flows through its playing surface, gliding the puck on a cushion of speed! Using the included custom dividers, you can instantly convert the playing surface for 2, 3, or 4-player gaming! Push button flippers and built-in arcade sound effects help keep the action fast and fun.

Components:

 1 Plastic game board (with 4 scorekeepers)
 3 Playing field dividers
 1 Angled divider
 2 Straight dividers
 12 Plastic pucks

From the developer web site:
"Stop or continue? In Kawumm! each player plays at own risk. After every round the player must decide if he buy three new ingredients or if he wishes to secure all the ingredients already collected. But if none of the drawn card matches his collection: Then it makes Kawumm! and all ingredients are lost.
- Card game for real gamers
- Fast to learn

name.value: Lock 'n Load Tactical: Heroes of the Pacific

item.description:
Heroes of the Pacific brings the award-winning Lock ’n Load Tactical game system to the Pacific theater with a vengeance. Heroes of the Pacific details America’s brawl with Japan during World War 2, and includes twelve frantic firefights from America’s audacious island-hopping campaign. You will lead desperate Marines struggling ashore on Tarawa, face a counterattack of HA GO tanks at the Peleliu airfield, fight for Kitano Point on Iwo Jima, and more.

It isn’t, however, all about the Marines; Heroes of the Pacific comes chock full of the U.S. Army’s finest, as well as the Imperial Japanese Army, all drawn with the painstaking detail our fans have come to expect.

It’s squad-level combat at its most exciting; it’s Lock ’n Load Tactical.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

link.value: Lock 'n Load Tactical: Compendium Volume 3 World War 2 Era
Lock 'n Load Tactical: Core Rules v5.0
Lock 'n Load Tactical: Days of Villainy
Lock 'n Load Tactical: Hell Frozen Over
Lock 'n Load Tactical: World War II Era Core Rules Manual v4.1

item.description: A tabletop soccer game in which you use two flippers to shoot the ball into your opponent’s goal.
Object is to collect the most points by throwing the sandbags into the point slots. Player or team with the most points is the winner.

Dice cricket is a dexterity and dice cricket game. There are no dates on the box or directions, but the general style suggests that it may be from the 1930s or 1940s. The directions (nothing as common as rules in this game) leave it to the players to decide how to organise the match - innings, numbers of players and so on.

Players put the pair of stumps about 5 to 6 feet apart ("the average length of an ordinary dining table" as the directions helpfully tell us). Dice are used as balls in the game. The bowler gently pitches a die (with faces 1, 2, 4, 6, out and NR (for no runs) to the batsman, preferably without the die touching the table. The batsman tries to hit it. If he misses and the stumps are hit, the batsman is out bowled. If he hits the die and it is caught by the bowler, the player is out caught. Otherwise, if he hits it, the result of the shot is shown by the top face of the die.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
This is a small promotion game in Brazil the works just like Top Trumps, composed of 32 cards.
Every player has a set of cards representing different ways to celebrate a Football Goal with points for creativity, beauty, joy, difficulty and irreverence. Every player see the top card of his deck and the star player choose a characteristic of his own card.
The player with most points in the characteristic wins and bring the looser's cards to his deck.
There is a trump ("Drink a Coke") that beats every card, except the card number 8, 16, 24 and 32.
When a player manage to take all 32 cards, he wins the game

Theme: Willy Slowman was probably the best intergalactic merchant ever to tackle the business. He started out with a hundred credits to his name and the keys to a small cargo hauler. Over the years he forged intergalactic trade routes, stared down pirates and amassed a small fortune.

When Willy died he left behind a sizeable fortune and a single stipulation in his will, that one of his relatives would prove to be the rightful heir to his shipping empire by following in his footsteps. Relatives started pouring out of the woodwork trying for a chance to win Willy's fortune. You know nothing about trade routes, or pirates, or the galaxy at large... but this is a chance of a lifetime. As one of Willy's recognized relatives (fourth cousin of a nephew, twice removed) the lawyers for the Slowman estate are going to provide you with 100 credits and a small cargo hauler, if you can be the first to amass 1000 credits you will prove yourself to be the rightful heir.

Gameplay: In this game the players race around the board to pick-up and deliver chits to amass their fortunes. The board is modular in order to increase replayability, and the chits are not sorted to decrease the set-up time (chits only have to be added/removed when changing the starting worlds - not the board layout). Chits include Events which have a timed effect, Goods, Passengers, Enemies which can harass the players or be hunted for bounty, Mined Goods and Ship Upgrades (increase your combat effectiveness or speed). This allows for a variety of gameplay strategies. The rules have been streamlined and every effort has been made to make it as streamlined and simple as possible without losing any of the flavor or depth.

But in the end the game is all about making money, and the first player to 1000 credits is the winner.

Race game. There are 80 squares to move along. No rules known to exist but is probably a roll-and-move game, with rewards and forfeits depending where you land.

The board depicts the Isle of Wight Regatta

Edwardian, British card game. The cards depict events from the Uncle Remus stories in the books by Joel Chandler Harris.
The game is a mix of Snap meets Happy Families. The objective being to collect sets. Children are encouraged to cry out "Brer Rabbit" when they see a matching card, and they must also read the quotation on the card.
Note that there were two different boxes used and it is unknown which came first. The box with the red surround has slightly different graphic under the quotation. The black surround box looks like it was printed slightly later, to me, than the red one.

Fishing season and Stores want lots of fish. Out to sea we go, putting out bait, hauling in nets, watching out for Sharks, always paying attention to the weather reports. Take a risk and get that last catch in?

The four Island Stores put in orders for Fish of various kinds.
Players are members of the Island Fishing Co-op, each with their own Boat, but who work together to fill these Store Orders, and return Home safely before the Stormy Season makes fishing and deliveries too dangerous to continue. They get paid for their work and share the earnings!

Contents:

 12 x 12" board, 
 4 fishing boats, 
 4 boat movers, 
 12 assorted fish, 
 4 sharks, 
 4 good weathers, 
 12 storms, and 
 16 assorted baits (4 are all-purpose), 
 the home supply depot

The Mayan Calendar is much more than a system to mark off the passage of time. It is a prophetic calendar that may help us understand the past and foresee the future. It is a calendar of the Ages that describes how the progression of Heavens and Underworlds condition the human consciousness, and thus the frames for our thought and actions within a given Age.

To some people it is predicting the end of the world, December 2012. For others, the Calendar is forecasting the start of a new Era. This game incorporates both views.

The object of this game is to create a physical vehicle like a pyramid to focus and spread universal spiritual power. For this task we will need builders, materials, equipment and money. We must work together to build 11 Spiritual Centers around the Planet to ward off the many Destructive Perils entering from many directions. How much of the Earth did we allow to be destroyed? How much new spiritual consciousness did we bring into being?

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: 48 cards with different values on them, from a halfpenny to eight old pence. Probably aimed at parents who wanted to buy an educational game for their children. Cards are revealed around the table and if the exposed cards total a shilling (12 old pence) or more then the first to shout that observation, wins. Very good to get children used to money and also good for their mental arithmetic calculations.

Cheaoss (Chaos + Chess) is a mind-bending game with chess-like mechanics.

Each player has a set of pieces in 3 or more colours. Each square of the board is also coloured. The movement of the pieces is determined by the combination of colours, and different for each game.

Pieces on their own colour are royal; a player loses if they have no royal pieces remaining.

There are three boards... a beginner's board with three colours (3 different piece types), a standard board (7 piece types), and an advanced board for masochists (11 piece types).

Roll Out the words!
Make silly or serious sentences in a crossword fashion using the words that appear on top of the dice. Use the most words before time is up to win.

1,000 Years ago, a Blue Witch cast a sleeping spell on Jewel, the Fairy Crystal Forest's magical unicorn.
In order to wake Jewel, fairy opponents must venture through obstacles in the Fairy Crystal Forest to collect 4 ingredients for a waking potion and collect 5 Gems to purchase a golden wand. The first to collect the 4 potion ingredients, purchase their golden wand and reach the Fountain of Dreams WINS the game!

Contents:

 Game Board
 50 Gems & Jewel Bag
 4 Fairy Movers, 
 4 Mini Wands 
 Pink Die
 4 Potion Tracking Cards
 16 Ingredient Cards

Fun Meal Caper, invented by a veteran elementary school teacher, provides multiple levels of strategy to entertain the whole family. Filled with amusing twists and turns, Fun Meal Caper keeps every player in the game until the very end. The goal of the game is to collect all the items needed in a "fun meal": sandwich, fries, veggies, drink, dessert, and a toy. Using higher-order thinking skills, kids learn to look ahead and plan their best move. The players also experience moral dilemmas within the game, which gives them the choice of being fair or taking advantage of their opponents. Wet floors, good deeds, trades, and taking care of Nana who left her glasses in the car makes it a unique and delightful caper each time you play!

Object of the Game is to be the first player to collect at least one of every Tidal Pool Animal Card to fill your sand pail. You can win the game with 6 different animal cards or 5 animal cards and a Treasure Pool card.

Players then follow, taking their turns, to the left of the starting player. Play moves clockwise around the outside track with the larger "squares" by rolling 2 dice. If doubles are rolled, that player may take another turn. You may only enter a Tidal Pool path by landing on the arrow marked Enter. When you enter a Tidal Pool path you may use only 1 die to move your piece. If you land on one of the squares in the path with an arrow pointing at the animal cards, you may pick one up and put it on your Sand Pail Card. You may get more than one of the same animal cards. They are good for trading or dealing with a sea gull snatching up your animal.

Naughty Improv is a game of story telling using cards depicting funny and suggestive illustrations. Each player is given a hand of five cards.

On playing a card, the player must build on a continuous, common story, with the new addition to the story having a direct link to the card played. Players are judged on the new contribution to the story, and if not accepted the player retrieves the card and also takes a penalty card from the deck.

There is no set play order -- any player can play at any time with the exception that no player may play two cards in a row. Points are scored for the number of cards played.

A round ends after a player has no more cards remaining. The player with the most points after five rounds wins the game.

The fast-paced 4-in-a-row abstract strategy game
Exercise your mind and outwit your opponents with Oversight, the new fast paced 4 in a row abstract strategy game! Oversight is set up on a board of movable squares. Two to four players compete to be the first to get 4 tokens in a row. On their turn, each player can either place a token on the board, or shift an entire row or column of moveable squares over by one space. The rules are simple but the game gets increasingly challenging as players learn from their mistakes and predict their opponents’ moves.
 Contents:

 1 game board
 34 tile squares
 48 playing tokens

Do your ABC's like you've never done before! Turn your ABC's into a hilarious and challenging game. Pick up a category card from the deck and think fast to find the words to match--alphabetically!

A, B, C might be easy,- see if you can get to X, Y, Z!
There are multiple ways to play. Try it on your own, go head to head, or compete in teams. Pick the one that best suits your group.

Object is to be the first player or team to reach the targeted point value.

Players pick up a card from the top of the deck. Each player in clockwise succession gives a word in alphabetic order (A to Z) relating to the category.
If a player gets stumped they are eliminated from this round. Last player standing wins the points posted on the card. If all players get stuck on one letter, the topic
is discarded and another topic is chosen.

Contents:

 101 Category Cards
 24 Wise Alec Cards

Break the ice and get talking with this outrageous collection of conversation starters. Or find out how well you really know your family and friends. Share your story, slip in a few fibs, and see how many people you can bamboozle!

This handy deck is perfect for parties, road trips, school, camp, or just hanging out with your friends. There are 4 different ways to play: The Chronicler, Kit & Caboodle, the Gamble, or Bamboozle! It's never the same game twice!

The Bamboozle
On your turn, pick up a card from the deck and without telling anyone else, choose to tell a true or false story. You must commit with your Voting Card whether the story is true or false before you tell it. After the story is told, all
the other players guess whether the story is true or false with their Voting Card. Players receive a point if they answer correctly with the storyteller. If a player is incorrect, then the storyteller receives their points. First player to reach 20 points wins the game .

Contents:

 119 Topic Cards
 6 Voting Cards

Rolling Stock is a card game about stock and company trading. Players are investors buying private companies in auctions, which they may later use for an IPO (to turn them into corporations) or sell to already existing corporations (to turn them into subsidiaries of that corporation). The majority share holder of a corporation controls its actions: issuing new shares, paying dividends, and buying more subsidiaries from other corporations, players, or an ominous foreign investor.

The companies are transportation themed, starting with the early Prussian railroad. As more companies are bought, the scope of the game expands to Germany, later Europe, and ultimately even space. With expanding scope, older companies become less and less profitable until they have to be written off eventually, severely hitting the book value of their owner.

As a pure card game, Rolling Stock has no game board to simulate actual transportation. Instead, networking effects are modeled by synergies between geographically adjacent companies that are subsidiaries of the same corporation. This simplistic model merely sets the stage for the trading of stocks and companies, which is the heart and soul of the game.

Rolling Stock is vaguely inspired by the 18xx series of games but it is clearly not a part of it. Obviously, track building is missing entirely, but even the stock market with all its superficial similarities turns out to be fundamentally different.

Compared to the 18xx series, Rolling Stock has extremely simple rules. Strategically, however, it is comparably deep and complex.

name.value: Criminal Blunder: Wargame Scenarios for the Battle of Pickett's Mill

item.description:
Criminal Blunder is an ACW miniatures game featuring fivescenarios on the Battle of Pickett's Mill. The scenarios range from a full battle scenario to a quick playing abridged scenario.

From the game's description:
"This game plays out the Battle of Pickett’s Mill on a regimental level. It is the full historical scenario including such details as the complicated Union command structure and brigades with 5-9 regiments each. It also places strict release times for certain Union brigades."

name.value: Musketry Like Thunder: The Greatest Civil War Battles Never Fought

item.description: Musketry Like Thunder is an ACW miniatures game featuring 11 what-if scenarios on the regimental level (although the system can be modified for brigade level). The scenarios range from small battles in an orchard to large corps level battles. Terrain and weather rules factor heavily into game play.

1917 is a wargame for five players on the Bolshevik Revolution. Each player represents a faction leader in Russia's government and the goal is to eliminate all other players before the Bolsheviks take control. The factions are 
The Kulaks, The People (general populace of Russia), The Czar, The Army, and the Aristocracy. The Bolshevik are not controlled by a player. Special events in the game such as Recruiting, Unrest, Solidarity, and Propaganda are randomly determined by cards.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Equipment: 27 cards with black numbers and 27 cards with red numbers, each showing a points number and 3 squares holding a combination of numbers and Xs. No rules but it appears to be a trick-taking game. The cards you win are then used to complete your Football Pools results on your personal score-sheet.
Football Pools were very popular in Britain, up till the 1990's, when the National Lottery came in and was simpler and more convenient the the Pools. The Football Pools required you to pick any 8 results from the professional games played that weekend and predict which games would end in a draw. If you got 8 right, you were a winner and the prize could be very substantial, even a million pounds plus.

name.value: Grammatical Conversation or English Grammar Familiarized

item.description: An educational trivia game. Each player plays an agreed number of counters into the pool. A pack of answer cards are dealt so that everyone has a equal number of cards. The host or hostess then draws a question card and any player can claim that they have the correct answer on one of their cards. If they are correct, they take a reward from the Pool. If they are wrong, they add some counters to the Pool. The winner is the first player to have no answer cards left.

War of the Psychic Gods is a fantasy fighting game in which The God of Reason has been overthrown and his opponent Gods are fighting for who shall reign supreme. The game uses the Steel and Glory system but changes the battle field to an Astral Plane and the traditional weapons to physic weapons.

Scarlotti is a science fiction board game which was published in the Britsh role-playing magazine, Imagine (issue 9 - Dec 1983). It was a two page article with a pull out card board and counters, and was sub tiled "An easy to play boardgame for up to four players".

Game equipment is a board and five sets of four counters (four stars and 16 ship counters), also two packs of playing cards are required.

The object of the game is to collect a star and return it to your home base.

The board is a grid with the the home bases at each corner of the board and the cards are for movement and combat.

The rules have also had a number of variants options.

The box promises "Enough to make you laugh".
160 cards with questions and answers. Unlike most trivia games, this is intended to be funny, especially when people give the incorrect answer.
First to win an agreed number of questions, wins.

You and your fellow voodoo spirits have traveled back in time to poke a little fun at the hepcats of the 1950s cocktail culture. Your mystical influences will link these lounge-goers into social cliques that give you access to the coolest party-people that all the hipsters want to be near. Mix a few drinks, rack up the magical monkey points, and crown yourself king of the Swinging Jivecat Voodoo Lounge.

Score monkeys to hang on your martini glass by adding Jivecat contacts to your clique and claiming Trend cards through skillful manipulation of your lounge contacts. Be the player with the most monkeys at the end of the round in which a player scores their fifteenth monkey and be crowned the winner!

Players are dealt a hand of four cards and on their turn use those cards for their face value to claim low-brow contacts in the lounges or use the card's special powers to claim Jivecat contacts and cast spells (Zombie, Rada, Cheval, and Voodoo). For example, a 4 Zombie can be used to claim a "4" contact in the Lava Lounge. Card values can be added and subtracted from each other, allowing players to pinpoint just the right contacts to advance their plans.

However, the player could use the card for its Zombie spell, instead. By paying a skull, they can place the card in their tableau as an extension of their hand allowing them to use that card's value for many turns in the future.

In these ways, players create "cliques" of linked contacts in and among the four cocktail lounges (Lava, Cocoa, Tiki, and Neptune) trying to schmooze their way to the Jivacat contacts that score points. The contacts are limited though, so several players may be angling for a specific Jivecat.

During play, a series of Skull Cards allow players to gain skull token reward that power their voodoo spells, and a Trend Card track presents players with monkey rewards for achieving specific contact configurations. The Trend cards also provide special bonus abilities to the players if they can maintain the required configurations.

Each player has a martini glass to hold the contact chips and scores are kept through hanging cocktail monkeys on the rim of the player's glass. Orange monkeys are 1 point and blue monkeys are 5 points.

Game end is triggered when one player reaches fifteen monkey points. The round is completed, bonus monkeys are rewarded for trends that have been maintained, and the player with the most monkeys wins.

To add to the cocktail themed fun, each card also has a different cocktail recipe for adult players to mix and enjoy.

link.value: Swinging Jivecat Voodoo Lounge: Bonus Promo Cards

item.description:
A question and Answer game with 96 question cards. Each player gets a board on which they place markers. First to get 12 right answers on their board, wins.
The box proclaims "A Game of Historical Interest.
Marked only as 'British Manfacture'.

Children's game featuring a Mickey Mouse target. The 'Bull' in the centre of the target is a delicate part of Mickey's anatomy.
The game comes with 4 plastic arrows with rubber suckers in the end, plus a pop-gun.
The first to score an agreed number of points, wins.

Action game. Any number of players may play. You have to hit the target with your white balls, a little like Table Tennis balls but smaller.
The target is a Clown's face with his mouth wide open. Players aim to throw or bounce their ball into the mouth for a good score, or into two holes below his face which scores less points.
Play to an agreed number of points.

Not a domino game despite the title.
49 cards, each with a syllable on. The idea is to make the syllables link together to form as many words as you can crossword-fashion.
Each player gets an equal number of cards and a set time to make their personal crossword.
There is also a 1 player diversion where you must make a complete crossword using all 49 cards. The answer is provided.

name.value: The Game of M.P. or Government and Opposition

item.description:
Card game with 52 cards. 27 are bordered in red and illustrate the government. 25 are black bordered and depict the opposition.
I have no rules and it is difficult to tell which game this is related to, but it is probably a set collecting game.

name.value: Historic Boston Freedom Trail Trivia Game

item.description:
This trivia game tests a player's knowledge of the Freedom Trail, the American Revolution, historic Boston, plus Cape Cod and New England. Contestants move around a board featuring actual locations in Boston. The pathway begins in Boston Common and ends at the harbor. Special cards might give a player the chance to continue moving even if he or she misses a question. The final routes to the harbor includes special spaces for the Freedom Trail.

Includes board, 6 tokens, die, cards, rules, and question booklet.
Promotional game, made to advertise Cadbury's Selection Boxes (chocolates). A simple race game. The playing pieces need to be cut out of the box.

A novel question and answer game. The questions are on one disc and the answers are on another. There is an electric probe that leads from the question and you touch it next to your chosen answer. It will then indicate if you were right or wrong.
First to get an agreed number of answers right, wins.

Trivia game that used 1920-style technology to impress any buyers.
There are 6 double-sided discs. Slot a disc into the box and read a question. Then, by a series of magnets, the disc will reveal the correct answer.
First to get an agreed number of questions right, wins. Limited replayability as only 72 questions are provided in total.

Players take turns acting as the "emcee", a moderator position, every round. The emcee randomly draws a card from one of several categories and reads the it aloud. This "cue card" contains an unfinished joke. Each Comedian (player) must devise and write down a completed version of the joke. The players pass their completed jokes to the emcee, who then reads them in a random order. Each player then votes for his/her favorite (beside their own, of course). The player with the most votes gets to keep the cue card. The first player to receive a certain number of cue cards (based on the number of players), wins.

The categories are as follows:

Punchline
The Cue Card gives the punchline to a joke. The Comedian (player) must write the setup (beginning) of the joke.

Missing Pieces
The Cue Card gives a one liner with some pieces missing. The 
Comedian must finish writing the one liner by filling each blank 
with one or more words.

What's So Funny?
The Cue Card gives the setup to a joke. The Comedian must 
write the punchline.

Bright Idea
The Cue Card gives the setup to the ever-popular “light bulb” 
joke. The Comedian must write the punchline.

Limerick
The Cue Card gives the first four lines of a limerick. The 
Comedian must write the fifth line.

Tie-breaker
In the case that two or more comedians receive an equal number of votes, a tie-breaker round must be played. The emcee draws a card from the top of the tie-breaker photo card pile and shows it to all comedians. Each tying comedian writes a humorous caption for the photo. When all captions have been completed, each competing comedian reads his/her caption aloud. The non-competing players then vote for the funniest caption. The comedian who receives the most votes receives the original cue card.

There are several booster packs.
